citeinfo.origin: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS)
citeinfo.title: Raster Soil Survey by State

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service

descript.abstract:
This georeferenced soil database is a representation of soil survey work completed using digital soil mapping methodologies. Where available, this data represents the most detailed level of soil geographic data developed by the National Cooperative Soil Survey. The associated data represents Raster Soil Survey class data, available in the State of North Carolina.
The spatial data rendered in the geodatabase result from Raster Soil Survey - Project Mapping. Raster Soil Survey is a reference to products of soil survey work completed using digital soil mapping methodologies.
A 10 meter file geodatabase raster layer aligns with the Gridded Soil Survey Geographic (gSSURGO) Database. Raster Soil Survey data represents the most detailed soil survey information for a given area within the Gridded National Soil Geographic Database (gNATSGO) product. Each cell is assigned a value corresponding to a single attribute 'MUKEY' in the raster attribute table to facilitate joins with soil attribute data. Additional information on methods and standards for Digital Soil Mapping and Raster Soil Survey can be found in Chapter 5 of the Soil Survey Manual and Part 648 of the National Soil Survey Handbook.
descript.purpose: The Raster Soil Survey was created for use in resource planning and analysis of soils data. The Raster Soil Survey depicts the understanding of soil spatial variability and the distribution of soil properties and classes beyond traditional constraints of scale and order in SSURGO. The Raster Soil Survey map and associated data were prepared by soil scientists as part of the National Cooperative Soil Survey.

idinfo.useconst:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, should be acknowledged as the data source in products derived from these data.
This soil survey product does not contain detailed site-specific information and is not designed for use as a primary regulatory tool in site-specific permitting decisions. Soil Survey Information is public information and may be interpreted by organizations, agencies, units of government, or others based on their own needs; however, users are responsible for the appropriate application of soil survey information. NRCS will not accept reassignment of authority for decisions made by other Federal, State, or local regulatory bodies. NRCS will not make changes to Official Soil Survey Information or of any supplemental soil mapping for purposes related solely to State or local regulatory programs.
Digital data files are periodically updated and amended. Files are dated, and users are responsible for obtaining the latest version of the data.

attracc.attraccr: The attribution is confirmed by display of the map data using the geospatial and tabular software, in review selected attributes and spatial relationships. All attribute data conform to the attribute codes in the Raster Soil Survey Project correlation document.

dataqual.logic: Descriptive attributes (tabular information about the raster) were developed specifically for the Raster Soil Survey Projects referenced in this Raster Soil Survey Area. The classes or Map Units defining the soil survey area are distributed seamlessly across natural landforms over a broad physiographic area, or provide detailed soil information in areas without digital soil survey data in SSURGO as part of progressive soil survey.
dataqual.complete: Completeness of maps across the area of interest was assured. A Raster Soil Map Unit is spatially represented by a 10 meter cell assigned to a class (Soil Map Unit). A Soil Map Unit is composed of the entire population of soil components found within.

horizpa.horizpar: The accuracy of these digital data is based upon the sourced digital environmental data references outlined in the Raster Soil Survey Project correlation. Positional accuracy is referenced as spatial tolerance for the project accuracy assessment outlined in the Raster Soil Survey Project correlation document accessed at the online refences cited in the lineage.

procstep.procdesc: This dataset consists of georeferenced digital map data and computerized attribute data. The National Soil Information System (NASIS) database was developed by NRCS soil scientists according to national standards. The Raster Soil Survey Map Units are linked to attributes in NASIS. A statewide file geodatabase (ESRI) was created using ArcGIS software to accommodate the spatial and tabular Raster Soil Survey data. Spatial and tabular data is packaged in a standard product consistent with the delivery of USDA-NRCS Gridded Soil Survey Geographic Database (gSSURGO). All structural and attribute metadata for SSURGO also applies to Raster Soil Survey data. gSSURGO is similar to the standard USDA-NRCS SSURGO Database product but in the format of an Environmental Systems Research Institute, Inc. (ESRI®) file geodatabase.

Classification and correlation is documented in the NASIS database for specific projects referenced in this dataset. Data development aligns with the stages and processes for Digital Soil Mapping projects as outlined in Chapter 5 of the Soil Survey Manual. Data development, and validation documentation may be cited referencing the 'laoverlap' table (Legend Area Overlap) - Legend Area Overlap Type: Raster Soil Survey Project. Raster Soil Survey Project correlation document contains supporting documentation for referenced projects. Documenation can be accessed below cited state under 'DSM Raster Soil Survey (RSS) Projects' at the online linkage: https://tinyurl.com/rwbbgj2

overview.eaover: Relevant attributes are the cell soil values. Raster cell locations are representative of Map Units developed from soil survey projects completed using digital soil mapping methodologies. Field investigations were conducted to infer the relationships between observed soil descriptions and spatially explicit environmental data. The Map Unit key (MUKEY) is used to link to information in the National Soil Information System (NASIS) tables.
overview.eadetcit: Relevant attributes are the cell soil values.

U.S. Department of Agriculture. (current issue). National Soil Survey Handbook, title 430-VI.

distinfo.distliab:
Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Department of Agriculture, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the Agency regarding the utility of the data on any other system, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. The U.S. Department of Agriculture will warrant the delivery of this product in computer readable format, and will offer appropriate adjustment of credit when the product is determined unreadable by correctly adjusted computer input peripherals, or when the physical medium is delivered in damaged condition. Request for adjustment of credit must be made within 90 days from the date of this shipment from the ordering site.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture, nor any of its agencies are liable for misuse of the data, for damage, for transmission of viruses, or for computer contamination through the distribution of these datasets.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) prohibits discrimination in all of its programs and activities on the basis of race, color, national origin, age, disability, and where applicable, sex, (including gender identity and expression), marital status, familial status, parental status, religion, sexual orientation, political beliefs, genetic information, reprisal, or because all or part of an individual's income is derived from any public assistance program. (Not all prohibited bases apply to all programs.) Persons with disabilities who require alternative means for communication of program information (Braille, large print, audiotape, etc.) should contact USDA's TARGET Center at (202) 720-2600 (voice and TDD).
To file a complaint of discrimination, write to USDA, Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights, Office of the Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights, 1400 Independence Avenue, S.W., Stop 9410, Washington, DC 20250-9410, or call toll-free at (866) 632-9992 (English) or (800) 877-8339 (TDD) or (866) 377-8642 (English Federal-relay) or (800) 845-6136 (Spanish Federal-relay). USDA is an equal opportunity provider and employer.
